Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: I am able to ping to to my other system but if I run **getpeerinfo** I am getting an empty array. I am using same asset chain name on both systems . Where do you think I am going wrong @Alright

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: port is open?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: instead of ping try `telnet <ip> <port>`

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: port is p2p port and is shown in getinfo

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: oh yes I think port is not getting connected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: firewall?

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: I dont think its firewall issue. I checked the firewall. Is it because telnet is not installed in my system?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Telnet is on every system, o e of your nodes must be behind Nat

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @SuSC135 if you can ping, but not other things, you probably have those TCP ports filtered by a firewall or one of the nodes itself

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you must open up the p2p ports on both nodes, and allow that port on any firewwall between them, too

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: rpc port is usually only needed on localhost

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ping uses ICMP, which is often not filtered by firewalls

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: My port is 12562 and i have allowed it on both nodes

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content:
**Status: active

To                         Action      From
--                         ------      ----
12562                      ALLOW       Anywhere                  
12562/tcp                  ALLOW       Anywhere                  
12562 (v6)                 ALLOW       Anywhere (v6)             
12562/tcp (v6)             ALLOW       Anywhere (v6)**

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: And when I run the netsat it shows the port is not bound to any ip address

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content:
```sudo netstat -tulpn
Active Internet connections (only servers)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name    
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:12562           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      2775/./komodod      
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.53:53           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      9011/systemd-resolv 
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:631           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      24441/cupsd         
tcp6       0      0 :::12562                :::*                    LISTEN      2775/./komodod      
tcp6       0      0 :::12563                :::*                    LISTEN      2775/./komodod      
tcp6       0      0 ::1:631                 :::*                    LISTEN      24441/cupsd ```

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: I think for issue isolation you may totally disable firewall / allow all traffic in your local network rules - if it works it means issue is here and you can setup it proper then from scratch. If no - have to find problem somewhere else.

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: There are a lot of tools to check connectivity / network configuration such as proposed above `telnet` or let's say `traceroute` (possible to provide port as param to traceroute as well - so you'll see where traffic is not pass / blocked), `tcpdump` is very powerful as well

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @SuSC135 it's easy to use `curl` to verify a certain port is open

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: curl will give different errors, based on whether the port is blocked, versus doing an invalid HTTP request against a p2p full node port

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: use `curl -v`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also make sure you are using the p2p port number, not the rpc port

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: I did both traceroute and curl. It seems that the port 12562 is not bound to the ip address of the node.  its rather bound to 0.0.0.0:12562. Is there any way to change this?

Author: cipi#4502
Content: 0.0.0.0 is OK, since it means it listens to all IPs that the node has... does the node have a public IP and not some private IPs? What is the IP of this node? `sudo ifconfig`

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: I am running two VM in the same system and the IP address is 192.168.56.1

Author: cipi#4502
Content: ok, that is another story... seems the 2 VMs can't see each other because the host system does not route traffic from one VM to the other... but i am not familiar with VMs and how the host system must be configured to do that, since i don't use VMs

Author: cipi#4502
Content: i would google for something like "virtual switch VM"

Author: cipi#4502
Content: so basically both VMs must be in the same network, e.g. 192.168.x.x and be connected to the same "virtual switch"

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Fopr VMs I use a bridged adapter.... let your router give each VM its own IP...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: this then works every time... and you can Port Forward a port to internet to let outside nodes conenct aswell.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: With VirtualBox this is pretty easy, just chagne netowrk adapter to Bridged. Using QEMU its a bit tricky.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @SuSC135 yeah, if you have VMs, you need to do extra work to allow them to get traffic

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i used vagrant in the past, and in the Vagrantfile, you can specify mapping a host port to a VM port

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's the safest default for VMs to not be able to access the outside world, so that is usually the default

Content: The article mentions these networking issues I have faced with @Bryan_Beus in various testing scenarios

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
And tbh docker provides the least networking headaches in exchange for some docker tool fundamentals.

Networking is a layer too far down for most devs learning dev stuff, compared to a devops tool which is closer to a new dev workflow

Content: The particular language you learn doesn't matter. Understanding data structures and algorithms is what really matters

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how to redefine a very difficult problem into something just a little bit easier

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: This is deep wisdom. And it is why Computer Science professors often can't code at all. You can't practice swimming by reading books
